note.p: St Giles' cemetery, now Ascension Cemetery, Cambridge
Education: City of London School (1871-1876); University College, London; Guy's Hospital MA (Camb); MB; DSc (Lond)

Career: Staff, Guy's Hospital, London (1894); Lecturer, chemical physiology, Cambridge, 1898; Tutor, Emmanuel College, Cambridge (1905-1910); Praelector in Physiological Chemistry, Trinity College, Cambridge (1911); Professor of Biochemistry (1914); Fellow of Trinity College, Cambridge; Honorary Fellow of Emmanuel College, Cambridge; President, British Association. A pioneer in biochemistry, he was the man who coined the word 'vitamins'.
Medals/Prizes: Royal Medal 1918; Copley Medal 1926; Nobel Prize (Physiology or Medicine) 1929
Obituaries: Obituary Notices of Fellows of the Royal Society 1948-1949 vol 6 pp 115-145, plate, by H H Dale
References: R A McCance, 'An Interesting but Forgotten Publication of Frederick Gowland Hopkins, PRS' in NR 1952 vol 9 pp 348-352
Joseph Needham, 'Sir Frederick Gowland Hopkins, OM, FRS (1861-1947)' in NR 1962 vol 17 pp 117-162, plate
